ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Better critical thinking skills for approaching calculus-based problems, and more confidence with calculus problems.
Fundamentals of calculus 1, applications (related rates and optimization), important theories.
I learned about what work I needed to be doing outside of class to stay up to speed in a college level math class.
I gained quantitative reasoning skills that will be useful in future math courses that I will take. I learned how to apply math to solve real-world problems.
Basic math skills and helpful insight to what a college math class looks like.
Resilience in understanding math
I gained confidence in tackling mathematical scenarios that have not entirely clear steps to follow and require problem solving skills
I fundamental understanding of single variable calculus
Single variable calc
I thought I learned a lot in this course in a short amount of time. That said, due to the rigor and pace of this course, wish there would have been more support throughout the semester.
Actually nothing. I feel like my calculus knowledge decreased while I was in this class.
I have developed skills that are related to expressing real world scenarios through mathematical equations and solving them.
Knowledge of basic calculus material
I learned the basics of Calculus I. Plus, I developed a greater understanding of the mechanics that allow us to derive equations in a certain manner.
A strong introduction into the fundamental concepts of Calculus and how they can be derived.
I learned about how to connect and apply the foundational concepts of calculus to harder problems and real work models.
Calculus one.
I further developed my understanding of calculus.
Polishing up math skills while expanding my knowledge in the field of calculus

I was able to learn more about the concepts of Calculus I, and less on just focusing on the process of solving a problem. It was helpful to address specific math-related questions for each class as I was able to understand math on a deeper level.
How to prepare for exams, using math to solve real world problems. how to organize notes.
I've learned how to take notes in a lecture type style setting and ask questions to best help my learning. I've also learned how to utalize help outside of the classroom such as peer tutors.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: helpful office hours, willing to take time to re-explain concepts many different ways until it clicks, engaging teaching style
Weaknesses: N/A

I especially enjoyed the derivative computer, as it forced me to learn how to complete derivatives almost immediately. I would have appreciated if more real-life examples of differentiation were not merely saved for the end with phase diagrams and differential equations.

Less focus on theory and more focus on how to solve problems/applications. There seems to be a disconnect between what is on exams and what the professors believe to be appropriate testing content. This was frustrating because it seems most logical for the professors to be the ones who are actually writing the exam content.
I felt like we moved through content very quickly and I didnt have time to grasp the basis before getting harder versions on the problem set.

The strengths of this course was that it is taught with a relatively small class size, so I was able to ask questions in class. A weakness of this course was that it was extremely fast paced and I felt that if I hadn't previously taken this course in high school, I would not have been able to keep up.

Strengths: helpful lectures and one problem set a week was manageable 
Weaknesses: not a lot of check in practice problems during the lecture time.
Strength very thorough and detailed I was able to understand elements of math I hadnt before. Weakness the course was too fast paced and catered to those who already took Calculus
I struggled very much with exams, however I felt that I grew in strength and confidence in my abilities to take exams. My final exam felt significantly stronger than my first two in this class.

The strength and weakness of this course is the amount of material that is taught. Since there is so much material that is taught, the amount of material is both a strength and a weakness. It gives kids a comprehensive knowledge of Calculus but can also leave some kids not understanding certain topics.
I think my professor was very good at explaining the concepts. However, I think we could have done more about applying the concepts like we are expected to do on tests.

Strengths: they were lenient with p set due dates when we had a break etc

Weaknesses: the teachers. They all suck and do not know how to reach capsicums and the way they grade is terrible. You could get everything right and show your work and still not get full points because they wanted you to do something they didnt even specifically ask for
I enjoyed the emphasis on collaboration (i.e through peer tutoring for psets). A weakness could be that sometimes it was easy to disengage during lectures

The class definitely focused on theoretical aspects of calculus I, which is fine if one took AP Calculus AB in high school, so they already have prior knowledge to supplement what they're doing. But, if it is one's first time taking calculus I, there are a lot of leaps made because of the heavy focus on theoretical that can be very confusing. Moreover, some things we did not reach, like u-substitution, and it was not clear on whether this would be covered in Math 115.

The in-class instruction was great however the actual assigned work could often be tedious. Additionally, if you did well on the first midterm but poorly on the second you're kind of screwed since the grades are only reweighted if you did worse on the first one.
Some weaknesses include assigning new problem sets the week of the midterms which was overwhelming.
The class size was large and I felt like the pressure to have to speak to other students in class was daunting especially if I didn't understand the subject at hand.

Because most of the class was taught conceptually, it may have been helpful to have solve through more difficult questions as a group. There were also some difficult questions on the weekly problem set that I wish we could have gone over during class.
Strengths: the math tutors were very helpful.

strengths: easy to follow, one pagers 
weakness: none 
improvements: some psets are very long

A strength of this course would be that the material is taught very clearly and is somewhat easy to understand. A weakness would be some of the lengths of the psets and it's material, considering how they are usually due on wednesday and half of the material required to complete it isn't avaliable till class on tuesday or wednesday.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, especially to re-learn calculus in a more critical way, where you learn why things are the way they are, rather than just internalizing and applying certain rules.
Only if the course was part of their prospective major.
Yes, I would recommend this course to other students because it prepares you for a career in STEM.
Yes because it is helpful to have one good math class under your belt. I took calculus in high school though so it was pretty easy for me.
I would Brett was a really awesome teacher.
Yes, excellent calculus class that gives students an idea of the level of understanding that is expected of students at the Ivy League college level
Yes. Specifically, I would recommend this course being taught by Professor Smith. He is a wonderful teacher and does an amazing job of keeping the class very interesting.

I would only recommend this course to another student if they really enjoy math and are good at math. Due to the intense pace, I do not think this is the best course for people who don't get the concepts right away.
I would try to not take it because its so hard to succeed and when you ask for help to succeed theyre not helpful. Literally none of the teachers can teach
Yes I would.
Yes, it was a straightforward course and I felt like I learned a lot
If one needs it for a pre-requisite for their major, then yes.
As this is a fundamental math class, it is necessary to take it if one intents to pursue fields related.
I wouldn't I think high school calculus makes more sense so rather than retake it I would suggest revising old work and skipping this class.
I would recommend this course to another student if they were somewhat familiar with calculus. It helps to gain a more conceptual understanding of math.
Yes, engaging class and well organized.
I would recommend it if they have taken a calculus type class in the past. It is very fast paced and some prior knowledge would be very helpful.
